title: Christie’s to Offer Art Collection of Ron Miller and Diane Disney Miller
text:
Text size

A group of paintings, drawings, works on paper, and sculpture from the collection of Ron and Diane Disney Miller will be offered across a series of sales at Christie’s in November.

In honoring the Disney Family’s philanthropic tradition that began with Diane’s father, Walt Disney, proceeds of the sale will benefit causes the couple supported during their lifetime through their eponymous charitable fund.

The collection features works by artists such as Richard Diebenkorn, Milton Avery, and Wayne Thiebaud, who were associated with The Walt Disney Co. Thiebaud apprenticed at Walt Disney Studios as an animator, drawing characters such as Goofy, Pinocchio, and Jiminy Cricket, which influenced his stylized realism in lively technicolor.

Diebenkorn worked in cartography alongside Disney animators in Hawaii, where he learned to translate three-dimensional imagery onto a two-dimensional plane.

Thiebaud’s 1988 Mickey Mouse, which brings new life to the globally beloved iconic cartoon character with bold colors and forms, will be offered during Christie’s New York sales of post-war and contemporary art on the morning of Nov. 13, with an estimate of $400,000 and $600,000. This sale will fund programs at The Walt Disney Family Museum in San Francisco.

Diebenkorn's Ocean#108 Courtesy of Christie's

Diebenkorn’s Ocean Park #108 is one of the series the artist made in his studio in the Ocean Park neighborhood of Santa Monica, California, over 20 years. The 1978 painting is expected to fetch between $7 million and $9 million at the evening sale of post-war and contemporary art on Nov. 13.

Sale of Ocean Park #108 and theremainder of the collection, which also includes works of art by Henri Matisse, Winslow Homer, Andrew Wyeth, Roy Lichtenstein, and others, will benefit additional causes the family supports.

Those beneficiaries include the Jane Goodall Institute, the HALO Trust, the Youth Orchestra of Los Angeles, and the Los Angeles Philharmonic.

“Ron and Diane Disney Miller ’s lifelong passion for the arts is exemplified by their extraordinary collection that extends across categories,” Barrett White, head of Christie’s post-war and contemporary art, Americas, said in a statement. “Diane’s close relationship with her storied father, Walt Disney, is evident in her keen eye as a collector and her dedication to philanthropic causes.”

The only biological child of Walt Disney, Diane Diwney Miller died in 2003 at age 79, while her husband Ron Miller, who served as president and CEO of The Walt Disney Co. from 1978 to 1984, died in February at 85.

Christie’s did not disclose how many lots altogether from Ron and Diane Disney Miller will be offered and the total estimated value of the collection. Some pieces will be sold during Christie’s sale of American Art in New York on Nov. 20.

Highlights of the collection will be on public view in Christie’s Los Angeles galleries from Oct. 15 to 17, and in San Francisco from Oct. 22 to 25.
